string-array.name: main_programming
string-array.item:
By this point, you should be able to control every part of your robot. It is time to stop working on implementing new features and perfect the ones you have. This is the time to create control loops which make the driver\'s job easier, such as a PID controller. Make sure to check if existing functions are available before trying to implement your own; they will be easier to use and are much less likely to contain bugs than code you or your team writes.
One of the features that is not stressed enough in FRC programming is code reuse. When writing the functions for this year\'s robot, think about how you can write the code so that it is still viable next year. Although your robot will change from year to year, there is no reason you cannot recycle some of the programming ideas and implementations. However, you may be required to release the code as open-source if you plan to use code from previous years, in order to comply with R13 of the Game Manual.

string-array.name: drive_practice
string-array.item:
Driving the robot at competition is an incredibly stressful job, and one that no amount of practice can fully prepare you for. In addition, no two robots are exactly the same, so experience driving from previous years will not always transfer. By Week 5 your team should have enough of a robot working to at least be driving, and ideally your team is completely done building and the robot is programmed.
By setting up a makeshift field your drivers should be able to get a feel for both the robot and the game. If your team has old robots available, try pitting the new one against a ragtag defense. This will give you an idea of what your robot is and isn\'t capable of doing. Don\'t forget to try and practice scoring!
